article.name: CrowdStrike Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
article.title: CrowdStrike Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
article.body:
In this article, you will learn how to integrate CrowdStrike’s Falcon Insight, an endpoint protection platform (EPP), with SecurityCoach. Once the integration is complete, data provided by CrowdStrike will be available for use under the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. This data can be viewed in SecurityCoach reports and used to create detection rules for real-time coaching campaigns. For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Tip:SecurityCoach also supports integrating Crowdstrike as a Splunk vendor. If your organization uses Splunk for security information and event management, we recommend integrating through Splunk instead by following our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.

Setting Up the Integration in Crowdstrike

To set up the Crowdstrike integration, you will first need to create an OAuth Client in your Crowdstrike admin console. To create your OAuth Client, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your CrowdStrike Falcon admin console.
  2. From the sidebar menu, navigate to Support and resources > Resources and tools > API Clients and Keys.
  3. A new API clients and keys window will open. In this window, navigate to OAuth2 API clients > Create API client. 
  4. See the screenshot and list below to configure and create your API client:
    1. Client name: Enter your preferred client name.
    2. Alerts permissions: Select the check box to enable Read permissions for Alerts.
    3. Create: Click this button to create the new API client.
  5. Locate the Client ID and Client Secret. Copy both of these items and save them somewhere that you can easily access later. You will need both of these items to set up the integration in SecurityCoach.
     
  6. Select the Base URL for your region using the table below:
    Region Base URL
    US https://api.us-2.crowdstrike.com/
    EU https://api.eu-1.crowdstrike.com/
    All other regions https://api.crowdstrike.com

Setting Up the Integration in Your SecurityCoach Console

Tip:Follow the steps in the Setting Up the Integration in Crowdstrike article section first to generate your API Client ID and Client Secret. These items are required to complete the steps below in SecurityCoach.

To set up the Crowdstrike integration in SecurityCoach, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training console.
  2. Navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  3. Locate the CrowdStrike vendor tile and click Configure.
  4. From the Cloud API Endpoint drop-down menu, select the endpoint for your region from the following list:
    • For the USA region, select http://api.us-2.crowdstrike.com/.
    • For the EU region, select http://api.eu-1.crowdstrike.com/.
    • For any other region, select http://api.crowdstrike.com.
  5. In the Client ID and Client Secret fields, enter the Client ID and the Client Secret that you copied in the Setting Up the Integration in Crowdstrike section of this article.
  6. Click Authorize.

Mapping Your Users

After setting up the CrowdStrike integration, we recommend mapping your users through mapping rules or through a CSV file upload. For more information about user mapping, see our Map Users in SecurityCoach article

Managing Crowdstrike Detection Rules

After setting up the Crowdstrike integration, use the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach to manage your detection rules for Crowdstrike. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our System Detection Rules by Vendor article. For more information on detection rules, see our Detection Rules Guide.

Deleting the Integration in SecurityCoach

If you want to delete the Crowdstrike integration from SecurityCoach, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training console.
  2. Navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  3. Locate the Crowdstrike vendor tile and click Edit.
  4. Click Delete Integration near the bottom of the page.
  5. A new pop-up window will open. If you are sure you want to delete the integration, click Confirm.

images.alt:
This image displays a dark-themed application menu interface, showing a primary navigation pane on the left and a secondary flyout menu on the right, triggered by selecting a primary item.

**Primary Navigation Pane (Left):**
This vertical list displays core application sections. The highlighted item is at the bottom:
*   **Support and resources** (Selected, indicated by a dark background highlight bordered in orange).
*   Other visible items include: Bookmarks, Recently visited, Endpoint security, Spotlight, Discover, Threat intelligence, Investigate, Dashboards and reports, Host setup and management, CrowdStrike Store, and Audit logs.

**Secondary Flyout Menu (Right):**
This menu is titled "Support and resources" and is organized into collapsible sections:

1.  **Support** (Header with a dropdown chevron):
    *   Support portal (External link icon present)
    *   Documentation
    *   News
    *   Ideas (External link icon present)

2.  **Resources and tools** (Header with a dropdown chevron):
    *   Notifications
    *   **API clients and keys** (Highlighted with an orange border, indicating the target selection or active focus).
    *   Developer portal (External link icon present)
    *   Tool downloads
    *   General settings
    *   Sitemap

3.  **Legal** (Header with a dropdown chevron):
    *   Terms and conditions (External link icon present)
    *   Privacy notice (External link icon present)
images.context: and tools > API Clients and Keys.

images.alt:
This image displays a segment of an administrative user interface (UI) for managing API keys and clients, likely within the CrowdStrike platform (indicated by the Base URL `https://api.crowdstrike.com`).

**UI Context and Navigation:**
1.  **Header Bar:** Contains a search function labeled **"Search"** and standard navigational elements including a menu icon, **"Support and resources"** link, and the current page title **"API clients and keys"**. Utility icons (notifications, chat, developer, profile, and theme selector) are located on the far right.
2.  **Section Tabs:** Two primary tabs are visible: the active tab, **"OAuth2 API clients"** (underlined), and the inactive tab, **"API clients action log"**.
3.  **Base Information:** The text label **"Base URL"** is displayed above the value `https://api.crowdstrike.com`.

**Key Action Elements:**
A large orange arrow directs attention to the right side of the screen where the primary action button is located:
1.  **Button:** A teal button labeled **"Create API client"**.
2.  **Contextual Link:** A hyperlinked text element, **"About OAuth2-Based APIs"**, is positioned adjacent to the creation button.

This image displays a modal dialog titled **"Create API client"**, used for configuring a new API client resource.

**UI Elements and Input Fields:**

1.  **"Client name" (a):** A text input field with a character limit displayed as **"0 / 50"**. The field is currently empty.
2.  **"Description":** A multi-line textarea input field with a character limit displayed as **"0 / 255"**. The field is currently empty.
3.  **Scope/Permission Table:** A section defining access scopes, presented in a table format with three columns: **Scope**, **Read**, and **Write**. A search bar, currently empty, is located above the table.
    *   **Scope Rows Listed:**
        *   Alerts
        *   API integrations
        *   App Logs
        *   Apps
    *   **Permission Status:**
        *   The **"Alerts"** row has the **"Read"** checkbox selected (checked) (b). The **"Write"** checkbox is unchecked.
        *   The remaining three rows (**API integrations, App Logs, Apps**) have both **"Read"** and **"Write"** checkboxes unchecked.

**Actions and Context:**

*   An 'X' icon is visible in the top right corner for closing the dialog.
*   The bottom footer contains two action buttons:
    *   **"Cancel"**: A standard, light-grey button.
    *   **"Create" (c)**: A primary, teal-colored button, indicating the final submission action.

images.alt:
This image displays a configuration screen titled **"CrowdStrike User Mapping"** within a larger application interface. The purpose is to map user identities between CrowdStrike data and internal user fields (KMSAT).

**Header and Context:**

*   **Title:** CrowdStrike User Mapping
*   **Description:** "Map your users by either configuring your mapping rules or uploading a CSV file below. Mapping your users to identifiers links events from this endpoint vendor to specific users. For more information about user mapping, see our **Mapping Users in SecurityCoach** article." (The article title is a blue hyperlink).

**Navigation Tabs (Mapping Method Selection):**

Two tabs are presented for selecting the mapping method:
1.  **Mapping Rules (Recommended)** (Currently active/selected tab).
2.  **CSV File Upload** (Inactive tab).

**Mapping Rules Configuration Section:**

This section, titled **"Configure Mapping Rules,"** is currently displayed and contains the following rule definition structure:

*   **Introductory Text:** "Configure your mapping rules to map your users to KMSAT user data fields. This is the recommended method for mapping your users."
*   **Rule 1 (Partial):** Defines a mapping relationship using structured fields:
    *   `CrowdStrike` (Source system label)
    *   `Hostname` (CrowdStrike attribute, displayed in a read-only tag)
    *   `is` (Operator, displayed in a read-only tag)
    *   **Knowbe4 User Data Field** (Target field label above a dropdown)
    *   A dropdown menu labeled **"Select option"**.
    *   A button labeled **"Add Field"**.
*   **Rule Expansion Link:** A blue hyperlink labeled **"Add Another Rule"** is provided below the first rule definition.

**Action Buttons (Footer):**

At the bottom of the screen, two primary action buttons are present:

1.  **Save** (Blue, solid button).
2.  **Delete Integration** (Red text within a white outline button).
